Situation1: They share only one open evening before a busy travel week.
Expectation2: Providing spiritual guidance and counseling to community members
Situation2: A community member casually mentioned wanting advice whenever the imam has free time.
Story: Tonight is the only evening I have free before a week of travel, and my boyfriend has been looking forward to it for days. He’s already texted me about the movie he wants to watch and the new place he wants to try for dinner. I promised him we’d have this time together, just us, no distractions. But as I was leaving the mosque this afternoon, Sister Amina caught me at the door. She smiled, but her eyes looked tired. “Imam, if you have any free time tonight, could I talk to you? I really need some guidance.” I could hear the hope in her voice, and I know how much she’s been struggling lately. As I walk home, my phone buzzes with a sweet message from my boyfriend, and I feel a knot tighten in my stomach. Both of them are counting on me, in different ways. I want to be there for him, to nurture our relationship, but I also feel the weight of my responsibility to my community. The expectations pull at me from both sides, and I can’t see how to meet them both.
